title: أَسْمَاءُ الْأَصْوَاتِ
description: Learn about أسماء الأصوات - words that represent sounds, including animal calls, human non-verbal sounds, and their grammatical treatment in classical Arabic.

notes.title: What are أسماء الأصوات?
content: أَسْمَاءُ الْأَصْوَاتِ (names of sounds) are words that represent or imitate sounds - animal sounds, human non-verbal sounds, or sounds used to call or drive away animals. They are also called حِكَايَةُ الصَّوْتِ (imitation of sounds).
These words are considered أَسْمَاءٌ مَبْنِيَّةٌ (indeclinable nouns) - they don't change for grammatical case. They occupy a unique grammatical category between nouns and interjections.

examples.english: Far be it / how far! (expressing remoteness)

notes.title: Types of Sound Words
content: Sound words fall into two main categories: 1) أَصْوَاتُ الْحَيَوَانِ (animal sounds) - words imitating animal calls, 2) أَصْوَاتٌ بَشَرِيَّةٌ (human sounds) - words for calling, driving away, or non-verbal expressions.
Some grammarians add a third category: أَصْوَاتُ الْجَمَادِ (sounds of objects) - like onomatopoeia for natural phenomena (thunder, water, etc.).

notes.title: Words for Calling Animals (أسماء زجر الحيوان)
content: Arabic has specific words for calling or driving animals. These include: words to call animals closer (إِقْبَال), words to drive animals away (زَجْر), and words to make animals move or stop (سَوْق).

Examples: هَلَا (to urge a horse), سَأْ سَأْ (to call a camel to drink), جِئْ جِئْ (to call sheep), كُخْ كُخْ (to stop a camel). These words are rarely used in modern Arabic but appear in classical texts.
keyPoints: Classical vocabulary, rare in modern use

examples.english: Word to drive away a predator
Word to make a camel kneel

notes.title: Human Non-Verbal Sounds
content: Arabic has words for human non-verbal sounds and expressions: آهِ/آهٍ (pain), أُفٍّ (disgust), وَاهًا (wonder), هَيْهَاتَ (remoteness/impossibility). These convey emotions without being full words.
These expressions appear in the Quran and classical literature. For example, أُفٍّ appears in وَلَا تَقُلْ لَهُمَا أُفٍّ (don't say 'uff' to them - Quran 17:23).

examples.english: Far, far away is what you are promised (Quran 23:36)

notes.title: Grammar of Sound Words
content: أَسْمَاءُ الْأَصْوَاتِ are مَبْنِيَّة (indeclinable) - they stay in one form regardless of grammatical position. They are typically في مَحَلّ (in the position of) whatever function they serve.
When used as subjects or objects, they are في محل رفع/نصب. Some grammarians consider them outside the i'rab system entirely - لَا مَحَلَّ لَهَا مِنَ الإِعْرَابِ (having no grammatical position).
keyPoints: في محل: 'in the position of' their function
Some say: لا محل لها من الإعراب

examples.arabic: سَمِعْتُ غَاقِ: غَاقِ مفعول به في محل نصب
examples.english: I heard 'caw': غَاقِ = object in accusative position

examples.arabic: أُفٍّ: اسم صوت مبني على الكسر
examples.english: أُفٍّ: sound word built on kasra

notes.title: Sound Words in Literature
content: Sound words appear throughout Arabic literature for vivid description and dramatic effect. Poets use them to imitate nature sounds, and narrators use them in stories.
Understanding these words enriches comprehension of classical texts, poetry, and the Quran. While many are archaic, they remain part of the grammatical tradition.
keyPoints: Used for vivid description in literature

examples.english: Far, far is what you are promised (Quran 23:36)
I heard the door creak: creak creak

exercises.prompt: الْكَلِمَاتُ الَّتِي تُمَثِّلُ الْأَصْوَاتَ تُسَمَّى أَسْمَاءَ _____
exercises.promptEn: Words that represent sounds are called names of _____

exercises.prompt: أَسْمَاءُ الْأَصْوَاتِ أَسْمَاءٌ _____ لَا تَتَغَيَّرُ بِالإِعْرَابِ
exercises.promptEn: Sound names are _____ nouns that don't change with i'rab

exercises.prompt: كَلِمَةُ أُفٍّ فِي الْقُرْآنِ تَدُلُّ عَلَى _____
exercises.promptEn: The word أُفٍّ in the Quran indicates _____

exercises.prompt: كَلِمَةُ هَيْهَاتَ تَدُلُّ عَلَى الْبُعْدِ وَ_____
exercises.promptEn: The word هَيْهَاتَ indicates remoteness and _____

exercises.prompt: الْكَلِمَاتُ الْمُسْتَعْمَلَةُ لِدَفْعِ الْحَيَوَانِ تُسَمَّى أَسْمَاءَ _____ الْحَيَوَانِ
exercises.promptEn: Words used to drive away animals are called names of _____ animals

exercises.answer: Far be it / how far / impossible (expressing remoteness)

exercises.prompt: A sound word expressing pain or discomfort
Words used to call animals or urge them to move
The grammatical term for words that don't change with case
